title: Rear Brake Caliper - Installation

body.body: Secure the brake caliper with the fixings and tighten sufficiently to bring the caliper into contact its mounting points. Do not fully tighten at this stage.
Connect the brake hose to the caliper incorporating new washers on each side of the union bolt.
Failure to fit the brake line in the correct position will lead to the brake line being incorrectly routed.
Make sure the orientation of the brake hoses are fitted to the rear brake caliper at an angle of 15째 (+/-5째) .
Do not release the brake line union bolt after the brake has been bled.
Releasing the brake line union bolt will allow air to enter the brake system.
Allowing air to enter the brake system will result in a spongy brake and reduced efficiency.
Angle 15째 +/-5째 (brake line to rear brake caliper)
Do not allow a brake component to hang unsupported on the brake hose or line.
Brake hoses or lines that are not supported may become damaged or bent.
Bent or damaged brake hoses or lines lead to reduced braking efficiency causing loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Do not loosen or remove the brake hose connected to the caliper.
Undo and remove the fixings securing the rear brake caliper to the caliper carrier and manoeuvre the caliper clear off the brake disc.
Make sure no damage is made to the brake pad material when moving the brake pads.
Allowing the brake pads to come into contact with each other or sharp objects may cause the material to crack or break.
Damage to the brake pads may result in reduced braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.

Obtain a suitable, wide, flat metal plate which is approximately 5 mm thick and place it between the brake pads. Pump the rear brake pedal until the metal plate is held in place by the brake pads. Make sure the brake fluid level does not drop below the minimum mark.
Position the caliper so that the bleed screw is above the highest point of the brake caliper.
Remove the rubber cap from the caliper bleed screw.

Whilst supporting the rear brake caliper, attach a transparent tube to the bleed screw and place the other end of the tube in a suitable receptacle containing new brake fluid. Keep the tube end below the level of fluid.

The bleed screw should only be opened by a small angle, just enough to allow system pressure to drop. When pulling the brake lever or pushing the caliper pistons in, some resistance should be felt indicating that the screw is not opened too much.
Support the caliper so that the bleed screw is uppermost.
Slowly apply and slowly release pressure to the brake pedal five times, maintaining pressure on the final application.
Open the bleed screw slightly to allow fluid to flow out but to still feel resistance in the brake lever.
Slowly apply and slowly release pressure to the brake pedal five times, maintaining pressure on the final application.
Open the bleed screw slightly to allow fluid to flow out but to still feel resistance in the brake lever.
Leave the bleed screw slightly open and slowly release the brake lever.
Slowly apply and slowly release pressure to the brake lever five times.
Close the bleed screw slightly to allow fluid to flow out but to still feel resistance in the brake lever.
Repeat steps 11 to 18 until no more air appears in the bleed tube/container.
With the brake lever still applied tighten the bleed screw to
Fill the reservoir to the upper level with new DOT 4 fluid.
Position the caliper over the brake disc making sure the pads are correctly aligned on both sides of the disc.
Fit the caliper retaining fixings, and tighten to

Use only DOT 4 specification brake fluid as listed in the general information section of this manual. The use of brake fluids other than those DOT 4 fluids listed in the general information section may reduce the efficiency of the braking system leading to an accident.
Observe the brake fluid handling warnings given earlier in this section of the manual.
Fill the master cylinder reservoir with new, DOT 4 brake fluid from a sealed container.
Attach the ABS wheel speed sensor harness to its clamps under the swinging arm as noted for removal.
Refit the rear brake hose cover to the swinging arm and tighten the new fixings to
Secure the lower end of the chain rubbing strip to the swinging arm and tighten the new fixing to

It is dangerous to operate the motorcycle with defective brakes; you must have your authorised Triumph dealer take remedial action before you attempt to ride the motorcycle again. Failure to take remedial action may reduce braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Check for correct brake operation. Rectify as necessary.
